One of my favorite geuzes. Bottle 2011-2012.

pour is hazy golden with little white head. Aroma of wet hay,lemony, Herbal, brett, dusty, horse blanket. Taste is tart lemon, brett, dusty, oak, light swetness. Low body and lively carbonation. One of my favorties gueuzes!

Bottle. Pour is pale yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is funky with light lemon, light wood, and faint gym sock. Flavor starts with a faint spice followed by lemony tartness and sour funk. Finish is lightly tart and funky with faint woody notes. A bit thin. Not a very complex Gueuze. OK.

12.5oz. Bottle at the Syb Pig in Boca Raton. Tulip. Golden pour with some haze. Light head and no lace. Aroma of all kinds of wonderful wild yeasts and probiotics, apples, green grapes and vinegar. Taste similar with a very acidic fruitiness and sour tartness. Wonderful mouth, tart finish. Wonderful.

750-ml bottle. Pours a hazy dark lemon yellow with a fluffy white head. Slight tartness with some dirty laundry funk and a hint of spoiled citrus for the aroma. Quite tart taste with lemon peel and a touch of honey before a very bitter finish. Very prickly carbonation, thin body, abrupt finish.
Bottle from City Beer. Pours a amber gold with a small white head. Aroma is very fruity, acidic and light woody. Tastes has very acidic notes, with some citrus.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2015 19 Mar 2015 - a great gueuze. dry, lemon juice, a bit of funk. excellent standard. 

22 aug 2013, bottle. Yellow, faintly cloudy. Nose is dry, sour, maybe some wood. Great! Thin body and faintly fizzy. Faintly sweet, lemon juice. Very dry. Really good.

Bottle. Wow! And.... Wow again! Big fresh manure, mounds of it, in fact. Light orange straw color. Seriously tart apple initial / composted fruit peels and light bitterness and a small metallic note / the finish stretches the taste buds with tartness and a savory, sunny freshness. Thin and astringent. Wonderful stuff. So fresh and right in your face.

This bottle might be slightly baked. It is about 35 degrees everyday here so perhaps it cooked a bit in the store. Slightly sour in the nose, a bit of oak/butter, but not much else. Mouthfeel is thin. A bit of a splurger out of the bottle. Taste is acidic and not terribly changing. One-sided for a gueuze. 37.5cl

Bottle. Golden colour with a white head with medium lasting. Aroma is very fruity, acidic and light woody. Flavor has very acidic notes, with some citrus and yeast hints, wood and old barrel sensation in the mouth and very fruity. The final is slightly bittery and acidic with good presence.

Dopo una fontana allapertura con perdita di 1/3 di bottiglia passiamo allassaggio...Aroma di frutta, aceto, limone. al palato acido, dolce, frutta, albicocca, limone, lime. Molto bolianciata con una gasatura importante che pulisce perfettamente il palato anche dopo piatti piuttosto complessi.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2014 Bottle: Velvety amber, cloudy with a thick off white head that settles fast to a film. Aroma is funky ass barnyard, old musty cork, dirty sweat socks, sour apples, lemon rinds, and biting acidity. So sour and so funky. Taste is impossibly sour. UPDATED: SEP 29, 2015 Color: amber orange beer with no carbonation and small white foam. Smell: floral and herbs nose with nice acid taste. Taste: fresh and light floral and herbs taste with a good acidity. Aftertaste: strong acidity with a good equilibrium.

Hazy orange with light, white head, no legs / Sour, bretty, foul nose of orchard & citrus fruit, barnyard, oak / Light body, lively, moderately sweet & sour, but mostly dry, excellent balance and lightly bitter finish / Elegant flavors of rotting fruit rind/skin (orange, pineapple, lemon, gingko, red apple), oak, straw, horse blanket / Right on.

Gueuze bij warm weer op terras in de Heren van Liedekerke perfect. Mooi bier met perfect schuim en goede Co2

from 375ml bottle into a wine glass, pours a hazzy orange color, with a white head. aroma of lemons, grapefruit, some peach, bread, taste is lemons in front, bit dry, sourness is ok, peaches, bread, some yeast, a really good geuze.

Bottle

Aroma: Nice tart fruit aroma

Appearance: Slightly cloudy straw color with short lasting white bubbly head

Taste: Green apples, tart, some slight bitter undertones and a bit of funkyness. There is a subtle pilsener bitterness that kicks in mid-taste and in the finish

From 37.5cl bottle got at La Birreria (Andorra). Hazy amber body with a small white head quickly disappearing leaving little lacing. Tart, funky leatherish, citric nose but it evolves in the glass after pouring to a more fruity, floral tones. Very nice complexity. Medium sweet and sour, light bitter and light salty. Label says 2011-2012. Best before Jan. 30, 2022. Pours a murky orange color with a white head. The aroma is full of cheesy funk with some lemon and orange notes. Pour is great hazy golden with a huge white tight bubble head that sticks to glass. Aroma is citrus and sour/ tart. Very earthy and sour with lemon rin notes that dryness that takes over the plate great. Its like a lemon head with out the sweetness. Very good beer.

Bottle a hazy golden yellow colored beer with a tight white head that sticks to the glass aroma sourness with citrus white fruits and lemons. Taste with lots of lemons rind and bitter very tart, clean drinking very refreshing.
aroma is light grainy with citrus overtones,pours golden yellow then slightly darker as yeast hits glass,taste is tart but less so than other gueuzes ,dry with long sour dry finish

Pouts a murky honey/gold color with a very small white bubbly head. Bottle - Pours light amber w/ white frothy head. Smells of some funk, tart, lemons. Its very well rounded. A nice balance of tart and sour with a little pepper feel at the end. So good!!!

Tasted this more times, first dec. 2011 from bottle.

This is great stuff. Tart, with some funk and good citrus notes. Extremely well balanced and put together.

Bottle at home bought at Ohtsuki. Hazy orange/light amber colour, small bubbly white head. Aroma is fruity, light funkiness, citrus. Taste is great, sherbet, sourness, fruit. Very nice flat creaminess. Nice sour sparkle at end. I love this beer, and my rating cant do it justice.

750ml bottle. Pours a hazy medium gold, with a moderate white head, which lasts well and leaves a little lacing. The aroma is a blend of dusty leather, funky sourness, oak and tart lime. Bottle at craft beer company, London. Dark amber body than some other lambics, almost looks like an IPA, but not in taste. Lovely refreshing sour taste here. A very enjoyable gueuze.

Reviewed 12/31/2012. Thanks to Momar42 for all three gueuzes (and the kriek surprise afterwards!) This was part of the gueuze showdown, pitting Tilquins gueuze against the juggernaut duo known as Cantillon Gueuze and Drie Fonteinen Oude Geuze. Part of a 750mL bottle poured into a Cantillon tulip. Notes from last nights Skins/Cowboys game.

A: Pours a cloudy dark amber color. The head is a one finger white shade, with the best texture and retention of the three.

S: Tons of tartness, a lesser white wine-esque fruitiness, and some buried earthy funk. The most seemingly sour of the three.

T: First thing that comes through initially is the combination of pear/apple esters and white wine tartness. The tart sourness breaks through more aggressively through the midtaste, while the finish is mild brett funk. Out of the three, this was the most sour, the least earthy - and the least subtle. Certainly a nice beer, however.

M: Super dry and puckering. Lots of carbonation, too. It lacks the delicate touch of the Cantiloon/3F gueuzes, though its softer than, say, a run of the mill Flemish red.

O: Its a nice sour ale. I wouldnt call it beginner friendly at all, though, due to the tartness. I would point fans of Flanders sours to this one, however. Shame it had compete against the two titans of the style - even though it came in third in the gueuze showdown, I reckon it would be superior to any other gueuze on the market (not from Cantiloon or 3F, that is).

Fresh sourness, medium body, nice aftertaste. Very good gueuze!

aroma is barnyard funk and a sourness.  extremely clear and orangish hue.  nice head formed.  taste is light, crisp, and tart.  detecting some sour green apple.  a bit of funkiness and sour on the finish.  wouldnt say its extremely sour.  just balanced enough to make it easy drinking.  not the most flavorful though.  seems a bit 1 dimensional.  would drink again but probably not at $10 for a 12.7oz bottle.

37,5cl bottle, BBE 4/2021. Poured cloudy golden with a thin white head. Lovely tart aroma with some barnyard, dried apricots. Flavor is tart, barnyard, apples coming through alot. Light sweetness. The finish is bonedry and tart. Excellent.

Bottle 37,5 cl, BBE 12.4.2021. Cloudy copperorange in color with thin white head. Sour, barnyard, sour apple, fresh with some vinegar as well. Loads of sourness, tart and fresh apples in taste. Sligtly sweet, but nonetheless very sour, crisp and tasty. Sticky mouthfeel. Nice, slightly sweet and sour fresh apple in aftertaste.
375 bottle. Pours golden with a thick, pillowy white head. Taste is sweet, funky, farmhouse/feet. Taste is sweet tarts with a farmhouse spiciness. Very solid gueze.
Bottle 37,5 cl. This is a good beer, but i can?t get pass the huge taste of jeast and grape. Not my kind of beer

Pours hazy golden. High fluffy white head. Aroma is very sour, yeast, grape fruit. Taste is sour, apples, ripe fruit, lively sparky feeling in the mouth. The finish is nice and leaves a sticky feeling on your teeth.

The nose was a bit shy on opening but opened up over time. Nice citrus zest notes and traditional funk. Medium-bodied with nice spritzy bubbles. Copper verging on apricot in color. Beautiful sour notes--enough to notice but not overpowering; citrus zest flavors with a hint of leather and copper penny. A very pleasant surprise-purchased on the recommendation of a shopkeeper who knows I love gueuze.

375 ml bottle. Aroma is kind of metallic with a lot of citrus, mostly grape fruit. Taste is heavy with grape fruit, nicely balanced. The taste was pretty harsh at first, but got smoother with increased temp/flatness.

2010 2011 375 bottle. Smells super awful, but in a good way? Sweet lemony funky and sort of smelling like a dirty garage with a touch of vomit. Really beautiful golden haze opaque with a good white head. Nice lemony character in the flavor. Sour but not unrepentantedly so.

750ml bottle shared with oakbluff. Gold in colour with spritzy carbonation. Superb aromas of lemon pie, herbs, funk, driftwood, and earth. Mellow flavors of lemon peel, pie crust, delicate yet savory kitchen herbs, and dried grass. Funky and sourish on the palate. It stands shoulder to shoulder with the magnificent gueuzes of 3F, Cantillon, and Girardin. Awesome stuff.

from notes - tulip pour of hazed straw with full two finger white head.  Nose is full!! tart apples, funk, crisp barn, straw and pear.  Flavor is lightly tart, tart apple, straw and grass, crisp and light tart finish with fruit esters.  Light and crisp body.  Great beer!
750ml bottle, shared by b3shine. Mostly hazy yellow / orange color. Good thin off-white head. Good soft lighter carbonation. Nice tart taste. Oaky wood. Nice

Appealing orange amber color with a fizzy 1" head and no lace.  Taste is tart sour grain (not really any caramel malt) with natural bittering in the finish.  Great accompaniment to soup and grilled cheese, probably just as good with any number of appetizers.  Unpretentious, refreshing, expensive ($10 for the 12.7oz. bottle!), recommended.

Bottle (375ml) from Vinmonopolet (Vika), Oslo. Hazy, bright orange/amber colour. Half-inch white head, quite good retention - settles as robust film with scattered bubbles. Aroma of barnyard, yeast, vinegar, apple, bitter orange. Light/medium body, lively carbonation. Very nicely balanced fruity and tart taste with a deep fruit-juicy background with just the right sweetness and vinegary acidity. Dry finish.

37,5cl flaska. Lätt slöjad börnstensfärgad öl med kraftigt, bubbligt vitt skum. Doft av surhet, äpplen, jäst och funkighet. Smaken är mycket fruktig. Omogna äpplen, citrus, grape tillsamans med läder. Torr munkänsla.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2012 Väldigt specilell. Den första Gueze Lambic jag prövar. Fantastik gyllene färg med enor mskumkrona. Luktar jäst och är väldigt syrlig med massa kolsyra.
Det är nog så här en Gueze skall vara?
Veramente buonissima, migliore della versione draft, più sostanziosa e rotonda, più lunga e intensa. Non ai livelli di altre però

Pours orangey golden with a small white head.  Aromas of underripe berries, citrus, herbs and barnyard. All kinds of citrus in the mouth, an explosion of fruity sourness, lemon, orange peel, more barnyard.  Wonderful Champagne like bubbles, and acidity that just begs you to take another sip.  Great stuff.

Bottle, shared with Dave. Hazy medium orange colour with a lasting finely bubble sticky white head. Aroma is sour and funky. Flavours of sour fruits (unripened apricot stands out), natural yoghurt, leather, and horseblanket. Some light vinegar too. Flavours all converge around a pleasant sourness that ends dry, with lower acidity than the 3 Fontein we had next.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Bottle (75cl) @ Villaggio Della Birra, Bibbiano. Hazy light orange with good, quite rapidly collapsing head, aroma is fruity and freshly sour: brett, wood, citrus, grapefruit and a little barnyard, taste is very balanced and smoothly acidic with vey good persistence in the whole mouth and a tempting dry finish. A monster of an Oude Gueuze, ive been drinking liters of this one and fall in love again every time.
Bottle (37.5cl) @ Fermento beer shop, Roma Via Tigré very similar to the 75cl bottle, but with clearer appearence (strange for an oude gueuze) and with less pronounced yeast and brett notes, the yeast deposit was really smaller than the bigger bottle and the overall balance was less pleasurable but still a very good beer. Anyway i would prefer going through  .75 Liters bottles, if possible, in the future.
Sample at a tasting. Strong sour smell, fruity with citrus, grapefruit and vanilla. Not a violently sour taste but enough to make it interesting. Nice.

Bottle. Golden with white ring of head. Aroma of lemon sherbet and barnyard funk. Similar taste, sharp lemon sherbet, lots going on but flavours that are impossible to describe. Long moderately tart finish. This really is an exceptional geuze.

23.08.2012. Bottle. Patricks Pub, Kristiansand. Thanks to Yngwie! Golden yellow colour, white head. Very sour aroma. not espesyaly rich, with medium body, a little thin actually. Refreshing beer with notes of poppy seeds...!

Bottle from SB (375ml). Pours a hazy medium yellow to golden, with a large white head that drops quickly. Aroma of spices, dough, champagne, a hint of banana, some tropical fruit and yeast. Taste starts off a bit mellow with a light, fresh sourness before a full head on explosion on the senses. Its incredibly rich with a powerful yet balanced sourness that manages to never become too much. Finish is abrupt and leaves off with a slight fruity sweetness. Body is medium, a touch oily almost, with balanced, medium carbonation.
Bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a large, off-white head. Tart/sweet aroma, horse, hay, whool and root cellar. Tart taste of lemon, red berries, grape and whool. Dry finish, medium body.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Aroma: Sourness, barnyard, leather, earth. Flavour: Leather, earth, sourness, light barnyard grape. Medium to full bodied. Ends quite sour. Nice gueuze.

The aroma of this ale is amazing, and that aroma just complements the great color.  Very tart to start, but I do like the invigorating first impression it gives to the taste.  Inhaling the aroma with the sip makes it a great combination to the senses.  Almost to sweet to finish, but a very fine offering.
Mix of subtle sweet, sour, dry flavors.  Refreshing delicious beer that would be great in kegs or cans. They call Gueuze the champagne of beer.  This is better than any champagne.

Hazy orange pour with a white head.  Little lacing.  Aroma is tart, citrus, barnyard funkiness.  Flavor is tart, biting, barnyard, grassy, leathery.  Really complex.  This beer just keeps unfolding in surprising and wonderful ways.  Tartness and carbonation and funk.  Really excellent beer.

Poured from a bottle into a stemmed wine glass.  Biting and tart flavor followed by a champagne like mouthfeel cleansing the palate.  Some fruit flavors life sour apples and a mild barnyard aroma from the brettanomyces.  Overall an wonderful Gueuze.

2012.09.15 - bottle 37.5cl - opening the bottle THERE is where it starts.  it=the pleasure (as the beer climbs the bottle, but doesnt gush out of it) -  green apple, sourness (taste and flavour).  As good as Botticelli.

370ml bottle @ Kaisla, Helsinki. Pours hazy pale golden yellow with a white head. Sour, pungent aroma with acidic fruits and fermented hay. The flavour is quite sour as well, with the taste  specific to Brettanomyces. A hint of grassy hops in the otherwise sour finish.

Burst into life when opened leaving 1/2 of bottle on counter.  Strong aroma of grapefruit. Taste of grapefruit pulp and lemons. With woody tones from acidification oak barrels. Not a beginners beer. Sophisticated and challenging like a conversation with Andy Warhal and a price like one of his prints.
375 ml from Shenanigans. 2012. Light orange with a nice touch of sour and vinegar. Bit of white grapes. Some apple tart. Dry but not overtly dry. Good stuff.

Peachy cloudy body with a thin bubble ring floating around the out sided edge of the glass. Big, big funky aroma with lemon candy, vinegar, white wine....so complex in a simple way. Big lemon sour funk, bret, vinegar, more stuff. Big tart finish that turns sweet and lingers. So very dry its just sucking the syliva out of my mouth leaving only SAND! The more I drink the more I think this is a a dry white wine. By far the easiest drinking gueuze and there for my favorite Gueuze I ever had.

August 19, 2012 - at The Craft Beer Co.  Courtesy of ... harrisoni?  magicdave6?  And I THINK this was the bottled version - frankly my notes are pretty sketchy on this one:  just the numbers and "sour, funky, lemon drops, wool, throat-clearing acidity, dry acidic finish, lively .... just what you want in a drinkin gueuze!!"  Dere ya go.

Bottle: Orangey coloured, cloudy, small white to off-white head, malic acid, vinegar, apples and cellary notes in the nose; moderate sour-bitter flavour, relatively light bodied and relatively soft as well; dry and tart cellary and fruity finish with a bitter aftertaste.Nice brew, maybe even better when longer stored.....

Bottle, 2010. Pours a hazy golden amber with a medium white fizzy head that disapears quickly with no lacing. Aroma is tart, brett, woody, white wine, barnyard, salami, citrus/lemon. Flavor is medium tart, quite citric, brett, wood resins and a bit of funk. Quite interesting.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2012 Cloudy, straw colored.  Excellent Gueuze.  Barnyard, sour, citrusy, tart lemom.  This would pair well with a variety of cheeses.  My only problem with it was its price, $17 for 33cc bottle!

Bottle shared at local beer tasting. Hazy golden, offwhite low head. Funky aroma with wood and grapefruit. Acidic taste, grapefruit, pine, with sweet malt in the background. Dry lemon finish. Quite nice!
Pours hazy peachy yellow. Smell is oranges, sour. Taste is tear jerking, apricot and lemon, very well done.

375 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse. Pours a hazy amber color with a thin white fizzy head. Decent head retention. Tart aroma with notes of pepper, citrus, caramel, earth and yeast. The taste is very tart citrus, berries, earth, vegetal notes. Tart and dry finish. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Damn good.
Bottle thanks to maltomeal. Pours bright yellow and hazy. Huge citrus skunky tart nose. Taste is very dry, slightly sweet, with a huge tart flavor. Very good.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text:
Bottle to wine glass
Sour, barnyardy, lemony and slightly smoky. Cloudy light amber with a thin white head. Sour lemon taste with a nice dryness.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2017 Bottle - Petrolium jelly and lemon sweetness.  Cloudy yellow with a quick dissapating head.  Acrid and sour, wine like.  Very dry hits the top of your mouth and back of the throat with a ton of bricks.  A fruit is there but I cant make it out, peach maybe?
Murky golden color with white head. Lemon, wood, straw, barnyard aromas. medium body. Lemon peel, dry hay, tart wheat, dry wood flavors--good gueze
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Poured at weihenheizens tasting. 375ml bottle shared. Pours a semi-hazy lighht copper with a creamy, thin, white head of foam. The aroma is strong tartness and some light woody notes. The taste is like the powder from a Warhead candy. Sour is about all this beer has going on. No complaints here, though. Quite good.

Refrigerated green bottle (drink before 5/3/2021) poured into a tulip.  Pours transparent deep golden with small white head.  Nice thin lacing, medium body, and nice sour aroma.  Taste is nice sour.  This is good.

Bottle at home, poured into my HF stemmed tulip. Hazy orange with a half-finger off-white head. Aroma is super funky and I love it. Smells of cobwebs, dirty socks, green apples, pears, wax, cheese rind, and urine but somehow it works. Tastes of heavy must, BO, sour apples, wax, lemon peel, and acid ending lightly tart and very dry. So refreshing. Medium body with champagne-like carbonation. Dirty, earthy, musty, and waxy, yet so refined and easy-to-drink. I am loving this one more and more as I continue to drink it. A classic gueuze and a must-try for anyone.

Bottle from Dak.  Pours a hazy orange-apricot color with a small white head.  Aroma has funk, must, some fruit.  Taste is both sour and sweet. Medium bodied with the tartness starting to take hold.  Very drinkable yet sour/tart.

37.5cl corked bottle. Hazy orange pour with large loose white head that rapidly dissipates. Nose of cheesy smelly socks, lemons, some damp wood. Palate is slick and easy drinking with a notable sour lemony taste and dry astringent finish. A fine geuze.
Hazy golden colour. Funky sour aroma. Taste is dry, sour, tart, funky, wonderful.
Bottle.  Hazy golden pour, white head.  Grass, tart lemon, leather, barnyard funk, dry, and a fair amount of acidic sourness.  Really nice, and a welcome change from American sours.

(375ml bb 2/3/2021) clearish medium gold, lasting fine white bubbles. Nose of wood char, Funk, herbs, yogurt, currant. Taste is the most tart gueuze Ive had, lacto, wood char, mild funk, currant and cranberry. Really nice.

Pours a slightly hazy orange with a small head.  Aromas of dirty feet, Brie cheese, sour crotch.  Blissful.  Taste is funky dry, sour feet, oaky goodness.  This is a wonderful, wonderful beer.  Amazingly complex and satisfying.  Love it.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours clear pale golden with low white head [second glass was hazy]. Aroma is of barnyard, funky. Taste is of barnyard, acid, funk. Palate is thin. Dry finish. Very good carbonation. Refreshing, drinkable, well balanced. Very good geuze.

Probably 2012vintage now from 1-3 years old lambik. Aroma isnt nearly as sour and sting as gueuze normally is. taste is more to buttermilk than whey. Good balance with the apples and some ale characteristics. Very mouthfylling.
Incredible for a new blender

UPDATED: APR 14, 2013 Pours clear golden with frothy white head. Lot of bobbles. Aroma: barnyard, fruits (green apples). Taste: nice sourness, fruity acidity. Lively carbonation. Medium to full bodied. Refreshing and drinkable.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2013 Bottle (750 ml). Clear golden with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma of barnyard, citrus (grapefruit), wood and leather. Taste is horse blanket, citrus, green apple and wood with a good geuze sourness/funkiness. Mouthfeel is dry and acidic. Lively carbonation. Very good gueuze and highly drinkable! Quite complex with a good balance, pleasant surprise!

375 mL bottle from Ealing Beer Festival poured into a Westmalle glass at home.  Fizzy head that dies away quite quickly.  Lively orange colour.  Typical gueuze aroma, acidic, good.  Fruity, very tart and a hint of sweetness in the finish.  This is pretty decent, but Im not sure why its had such rave ratings.
Poured a cloudy golden color from the bottle, aromas of light sourness, sme light tart fruit, and some tartness.  Favors follow the aromas, with a dry finish, nice little beer overall.

Great Gueuze. First example that was blended from several brewers that I have tried. Everything that I look for was here. Spritzy citrus, plenty of dry funk, wet basement and barny taste. For the price it may well be my go to gueuze.
Bottle from Kensington Wine Market in Calgary.

Bottle 375ml vintage 2010-2011 @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours cloudy deep golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of sour, stable, fruity and tart. Taste is light to medium sweet and medium sour with a long sour and dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft to fizzy
Bottle 75 cl. Hazy light orange body, sprakling. Small rocky white head. Aroma of citrus, apple and yeast. The taste is heavy sour, light bitter and sweet. I miss some bite and soul.

@ the hotel in Amsterdam, Pours beautiful orange to yellow with a nice head, aroma of brett, barnyard, hay and some leather, flavor is sour and dry with wood, lemon, vinegar, rubber and soil, medium to full bodied, excellent gueze

A remarkable example of the style, extremely light and delicate tartness with funk notes and savory fruity character.  A remarkable specimen, Im very happy that this is available in the US.  Stone Sour Fest 2012 and also generously shared by Zack S.
An excellent gueuze that brings a lot of complexity, funk and mustiness.  Yet is refreshing, tart, with a progression of flavors.  Finishes bright and sour and yummy.
incredible like almost every real gueuze, sourness and tart are incredibly powerful. Barnyard feel. Very good!

2010-2011 bottle - Pours hazy yellow-orange with a small, white, bubbly head. The wild funkiness dominates the aroma. We want the funk! The flavor is full of that good farmhouse, earthy, tart funk. Its medium bodied with a lasting taste of wild yeast in the dry finish. It works well. Ive had better lambics, but this is good.

Pours a bright and cloudy orange color with a large white head. A bursting aroma of hay, lemons, dust, funk. The flavor is a vigorous gueuze; initially quite sour, not acidic but very tart, some sweet wheat, loads of lemon and oranges. Certainly quite drinkable and refreshing with a huge bite of sourness. Of course lots of carbonation. Good, very damn good. The value for money is excellent and this may be my go-to-gueuze in my market.

Rating #1500!!! Its been a long, strange trip. Shared with my friend Barry, and served in a wine glass. Pours cloudy orange, with a thin white head, and poor lacing. Nose is tart and juicy, nice and sweaty like I like, but not as aggressive as say, a Cantillon, nor as delicate as a Drie Fonteinen, almost most similar to a Girardin, but fuller. Flavours of apricot, sweat, navel orange, dry earth, very tight and aggressive on one hand, yet juicy and giving on the other. maybe doesnt pack the "Rare" like Cantillon or Drie Fonteinen, but this certainly has the chops to match up with either. Decadent and delicious.

Pours a beautiful slightly hazy honey color with off white head that slowly drops to a thick blanket. Great nose, somewhat funky, tart green apples, wet paper, citrus. Taste is a little more subdues than the nose but nice non the less. Taste is grapefruit, lemon, green apples a little funk tart and dry finish. Light body active and delicate carbonation. A very nice, easily approachable gueuze.

2010-2011 bottle.
Bright golden, after a refill completely opaque, with a large off-white head.
Aroma: fruity with lemons and apples.
Taste: tart, but not that sour, green apples, lemons, dry white wine.
Medium-bodied with high carbonation.
A nice, fresh-tasting gueuze without funk and old dish rags.

375ml green bottle, corked. 6.4%abv on label. Deep gold with haze, white head dies out fairly quickly leaving a light ring of bubbles and an absence of lacing. Some sharp lemon in the nose, mild solvents that are strange but not out of place in the style, white sweetish grape, faint apple and other evolving fruit hints as it warms. Lemony taste, pleasing sourness, late mustiness. Excellent dryness. This gueuze has high drinkability and is pretty accessible for the style, medium complexity. Will gladly buy this again.

Bottle at Björn, thanks.
Short white head. Cloudy orange color.
Crisp dry Gueuze aroma with just a tuch of acidity. This is the same in the taste but with a small tart finnish.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 Bottle at Toms Lambic tasting, Craft Beer Co. This is a blend of Girardin, Boon and Lindemanns. Hazy amber thin white head. Nose is volcanic rock, green apples, pineapple, cider. A lot of fruit and green apple. Taste is sour, green apples, fresh granny smith sour, crisp. Good sour one. 5/10/12 rerate in Craft Brixton. Its clearer and crisper than Cantillon and Boon despite being a blend, has its own distict style. Stand by 3.8

375ml corked bottle listed at 6.4%ABV pours a hazy golden orange color with a finger of white head that settles to reveal no lacing on the glass.  Aroma is light fruits with hints of yeast and grass.  Taste is sour with grapefruit and lemon with some malty sweetness.  Medium bodied and highly carbonated with a dry finish.  Quite a well done Gueuze that is definitely recommended.

Bottle at Le Poechenellekelder

Pours a hazy blonde color with a thick fluffy white head that leaves good lace on the glass.

The aroma is funky in a funky ol cheese kind of way. Some lemon rind and plenty of barnyard funkiness in the aroma as well. 

The flavor is tart with lots and lots of lemon character and citrus rind. This one is on the higher end of the sour scale for gueuze but its also very crisp and refreshing. Easy to drink a whole bottle of out of a gueuze glass by ones self but complex enough to sit around with snifters and analyze. 

Excellent beer.

Corked demi bottle from Beer Planet, Brussels, marked 2010 2011, bb 22/12/2020Hazy blond color, with a darker shade; well carbonated, with a quite generous head. The aroma is strong, permeating the room, with very nice notes of cellar, Bretts and cobwebs in the beginning (8); some different kind of acidity follows, sweat, and traces of lemon and puke (7). Lean body, the mouthfeel has some more smoothness than other Gueuzes, it has the high acidity and lemon character of younger Lambics, but with a nice astringency in the end. Good, with moderate character and complexity.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2013 375 ml bottle @ Patricks. Hazy orange body with a big, beautiful lasting off-white head and heavy carbonation. Aroma has lots of fruit, specially grapefruit, hint of lemon and relatively moderate funk/barnyard. Flavor is incredible fresh and fruity, pleasant acidic  and again a bit more moderate in the funk department. Medium body, tart aftertaste and all in all brilliant balanced. This beer is for real and all the aroma and flavors are authentic geuze, at the same time this is not on the challenging side and should be a nice place to start for the skeptic sour beer drinker. Dificult to dislike this, I think I could drink this beer all night long wile waiting for next years version and hoping for something a bit more rough edge.
750 bottle @Cajun Sourfest-pours cloudy gold with a white head.  Aroma is sour medium fruit, barn, light malt.  Taste is sour medium fruit, yeast, barn, light malt.  Easy.

Bottle. Hazy gold pour, white head, little retention/lace. Aroma is sour, lemon, citrus, mineral, sourdough bread. Taste is quite sour, lemon, white grape, oak, dust. Palate is dry, mineral, high carbonation, sour finish. Good stuff.

Bottle @ CPK. Deep amber color with a big, eggshell white head. The nose is pressed moldy lemon, light yeast, funky orchard fruits and pleasant sugar cookie. The taste is lightly funky green apple and lemon peel, some light cheese and yeast. Dried dusty wood and bright citrus concentrate. Pleasantly light and deft. Active carbonation. Overall, quite refreshing and most quaffable. I like.

Bottle to glass.  Looks good; orange with nice carbonation, but not overly heady.  Smells nice; geuzy.  Tastes pretty good, although I wish it had a bit more funk and complexity.  Good on the palate.  Behind Cantillon and Drie, but ahead of most of the rest.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet Lambertseter enjoyed at home
Straw yellow hazy, white head. Smells of funk, musty barnyard, wildberries and mint. Taste is light sweet, medium to heavy sour of lactic acid, green apples and unripe berries. Some very light hints of bitter dry green apples back on the palate. Ligth body, lively carbonation, watery bubly texture. A very nice gueuze, maybe a bit on the kind side, but still quite complex

2010/11 vintage. pours a golden blonde with hints of orange. slight haze. fizzy head that retains fairly well. very bright and vivid on the nose. lots of lemon zest and oak. funk hides a bit beneath. very tart and sour. starts out more tart up front, and a deeper sour through the finish. typical lemon up front with a deep oak and funk. sour green apple emerges towards the finish. lots of carbonation, a bit too much at times. some dryness. very young but good. i am curious what age does to this. i can see it drying out a bit, maybe some more oak coming out.
Hazy mid-amber with citric nose with goaty butyric advert. Sour initially, then lemon pith, sherbert and quite Fruity finish.

Bottle @ Rasmus place. Pours golden with a small white head. Aroma of barnyard, dusty, some sweetness aswell, sour fruit, grapes, cheese. TAste is barnyard, stable, cheese, dusty, grapes, sour fruit. Thin body, lively carbonation, dry sour finish. 240512

Wow, excellent brew! Poured cold with a large, off-white, foamy, frothy, thick head that lasts a while and lots of lace. Color is a slightly hazy amber with a load of tiny bubble trails. Aroma is yeast, sour, bread dough, malt - a fresh and clean quality. Flavors like nose, fresh and clean, very dry with bitter and carbonic working very well with each other. Back of the tongue is left with an astringent feel. Body and carbonation are perfect. Finish is like flavor, with a slight dry champagne flavor and again very clean. Outstanding.

Pours a bright copper/gold with a thick fluffy head. Aroma of funk, apples and vinegar. Taste follows with strong oaky notes. Tart and refreshing. Very nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.  Aroma is funk (smells like a dirty garbage disposal) and wood.  Taste is wood, the same funk, and a nice intense tart sourness.

2010/2011 bottle.  Pours hazed orange/yellow; solid bright white head.  Nose a blend of mellow cheesy funk and iron with hints of flowers.  Flavors are nicely integrated; slightly solventy funk notes, blended for perfectly balanced sourness, white grape notes lingering in the finish with a dryness underneath.  Good stuff; a bit overly grapey in the finish where Id prefer something funkier, but good stuff.

375ml bottle. Sweet and sour aromas. Pours cloudy orange, with vanishing nice white head, leaving some lacework. Light body, high carbonation, crispy texture. Taste is a bit fruity, herbal, moderate sourness, well balanced. Long dry aftertaste. Very enjoyable.

Zythos Bierfestival 2012, Leuven, Belgium. It pours sort of orange gold with thin near white head of foam. The aroma offers up musty dank citrus fruit, some basement dankness and wet horse like goodness. Yes! The aroma is rich and deep and involved with yumminess. I also get tart vinegar nuances sort of circling around the edges. The taste is thin and smooth and running from rich sour notes to modest tartness and then rivers of vinegar coursing through the middle. It ends dry and somewhat sour and tart and funky yumminess. Now this I like, damn!

Poured from 375ml bottle. Appearance was bright yellow with thin white head. Nose was earthy, vinegar, acidic. Palate was sour with a vinegar undertones, green apple, a little peach and lots of lemon.

Bottle, Geers. 37,5 cl. Pours hazy straw/orange. Barnyard and horsesweat nose, very saliva pungent very astringent. Citrus sourness all round. Overattenuated, too much carbonation, not very round as well. Its oude geuze, with the most minimal amount of oude geuze... I prefer the Cantillon, Girardin & Boon geuzes all individually over this one.

11 bottle.  Hazy golden and yellow pour with a frothy white head and steady, active carbonation.  Aroma is classic gueuze with cheese rind funk, oak, and lemon.  I also get a slightly white wine vinuous quality in the aroma.  Taste has a nice funk with tart and quenching lemon, light grain, and a more focused funk/tart into the finish.  Light and fairly dry mouthfeel.  Not as complex and sharp as some of the best takes on the style Ive had but this is still a damn fine gueuze.  Great beer.
37,5cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours hazy amber with a white head. Funky aroma with barnyard and citrus. Dry, fruity and citric. Very dry and quite sour finish. Very refreshing. (2012-05-26)

375ml bottle shared with the wife on a lazy Memorial Day weekend.  Pours a golden color with white head that retains through about half the glass. Aroma is lemon zest, funk, feet as it warms up. UPDATED: NOV 20, 2012 2011 vintage. Managed to have this in June 2011 (when it was fresh, good but way underdone) in Sept 2011 (when it had turned to a strong sour gueuze) and in May 2012 when it had matured into a smooth complex sour. Hazy orange pour with a fizzy white head. Body is improved by the fact that it is unfiltered. Tastes of multiple fruits such as peach, cherry, orange, apricot, apple, grapefruit and red raspberry. End result is a well blended very sour gueuze. Smooth in flavor, though the sour bite remains strong through the finish. After a year of this first vintage it still has a lot of character and should continue to age well. Update: Having the 2011 once again in November 2012. Big difference this time. Clear, crisp and complex. Flavors now blended like a well aged white wine. Still sour but much more rich vinous notes. Excellent.

(Une belle bouteille de 75 cl, à consommer de préférence avant le 22 janvier 2021) Je suis à verser le premier verre de ce liquide à la robe dorée/orangée et je mattarde un instant au texte de létiquette.  On peut y lire : «La Gueuze Tilquin à lancienne est issue de lassemblage de lambics de 1, 2 er 3 ans mûris en fûts de chêne.  Non filtrée et non pasteurisée, elle est refermentée en bouteille.  Les lambics employés ont été brassés par les brasseries Boon, Lindemans, Girardin et Cantillon.»  Prometteur!  Donc, sur cette robe, une tête qui est a priori énorme et qui semble bien vouloir résister un instant.  Un regard qui permet aussi de constater le fort déplacement des bulles.  Une belle et bonne effervescence, quoi.  Au nez, les parfums sont bien cohésifs sans être expansifs : il y a une légère poussière et certainement un boisé avec des effluves de cuir et des citrons qui saccordent sur le même pas et qui ne tombent jamais dans lexcès.  Au niveau des saveurs, lassemblage des lambics est tout de même gentil pour mes papilles.  Il y a des notes fruitées surettes et acides.  Il y a des microbes et un goût de bois touché par les aléas de lhumidité.  Il y a des notes qui ne sont jamais trop intenses et jamais vinaigrées.  En bouche, cest un liquide qui étonne avec un corps de moyenne densité.  Il y a un apport de bulles qui est juste.  La texture est légèrement huileuse.  Japprécie cet état de fait.  En finale, une tempête asséchante, toute en équilibre avec une complexité certaine.  Facile à boire.  Peut-être un peu trop!

Bottle.  Pours a mostly clear dark gold body with a one finger fizzy white head that retained as a thin covering.  The nose is pretty nice, funky as all get out with some nice lemon rind and woody notes.  Very much smells like an authentic Gueuze, its great to have a new and available Gueuze on the market.  The flavor is very dry and nicely tart with the perfect amount of tartness and zero acetic acid.  Very drinkable and refreshing.  Bone dry on the finish with perfect fizzy carbonation.  A very good Gueuze, going to have to stock up with more of these.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2012 Bottle from Knightly.  Best by 2/15/2021.  Yup, Im inside that window.  Amber-gold, thin lasting off-white head on top.  This has that musty basement smell thats a good thing in these lambics.  Some bandaid, lemon, and citric acid too.  Sharp sour fruit flavor of grapefruit, lemon, and perhaps lime, but the sourness isnt over the top or anything.  Actually, its quite drinkable and refreshing. Plenty of straw and basemunt funk.  Very dry, long-lasting finish.  This is excellent stuff.  The more I drink it the more I am liking it.

350ml bottle - $9.49 at Hop City in Atlanta, Georgia. Best before: 15/02/2021.

Appearance: Pours out a lightly hazed, dark golden body with a medium-sized, white head.

Smell: Soured citrus juice, a slight rustic quality, stray oak shavings, rubbed leather, and a fair amount of drool-inducing lactic acid entering the nostrils.

Taste: A refreshing wash of Matt Simpsons Gas Line Lemonade with a fruity underpinning, an additional distant hint of lime rind, traces of antique pressed flowers, a dusty, leathery funkiness, and oaken planks. Moderately acidic but not enough to knock your teeth out, just enough, really. Dry, soft finish.

Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Lightly carbonated.

Overall: Politely discreet, refreshing, and just a good gueze overall.

Bottle corked. Poured clear golden color with an large frothy white head that was lasting with good lacing. Moderate sour yeasty wood aroma. Medium body with a dry texture with lively carbonation. Medium sour citrus flavor with a medium sour finish of moderated duration. This is a standout for style beer.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2016 Latest review, December 2016 - 37.5cl bottle, 2014 vintage. It pours a hazy golden color with a large white head. Some slow gushing upon uncorking. Aroma is full on funky and citric notes, big horse blanket, lemon peel, lemon juice, straw, grass, basement dust, must. Taste verges more on the acidic citric lemon juice upfront, with funk kicking in later in the sip. More lemon juice upfront, lactic acid, funky esters, basement and must. Burps hold some vinegarish sourness. As it warms up, the funk becomes more prominent behind the strong lemony initial note. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. Overall, my notes compare quite similarly to the 2012 ones and the strong citrus game is still on point. Score also remains unchanged 8-4-8-3-18

Original review, March 2012 - 75cl bottle, 2011 vintage. It pours a slightly hazy golden color with a big white head. Medium  kasting foam. Aroma is sour and funk with strong citrus notes. Hay, barnyard and dust as well. In the taste you get horse blanket, hay, lemon zest and juice, taleggio cheese and dust. Quite funky and sour with a nice sweetish touch. Medium to thin body with lively carbonation. Extremely balanced and tasty. Quite complex bouquet as well. Top notch for sure. Score: 8-4-8-3-18
hazy orange coloured body with a white head a sour fruity aroma a sour fruity little bitter taste with a sour finish
Corked bottle. Oak, dust, lemon and peach in the aroma. Sour, oaky flavor with grapefruit, lemon and pineapple. Good, sour, fairly complex geuze.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/28/2011.  Poured from a 350 mL bottle into a tulip. Thanks to bauermj for bringing this over.

My pour is a very hazy pale yellow color with a thin white head. The head remains mostly an island with a few spots of lace. 

The aroma is tart and acidic. A nice level of barnyard funk as well. Some soft malt presence in the back.

Tart lemon, a bit of grainy malt, and lots of pleasant sour flavors dominate the flavor. The finish has a good level of funk in it. 

The mouthfeel is definitely acidic. Light to medium body, light bubbly carbonation. Lightly puckering.

Overall, this is a solid gueuze.

Bottle: Poured a clear bright golden color lambic with a super huge foamy head with great retention and some good lacing. Aroma consists of light sour notes with light funky ester. Taste is also a mix between some sour and tart notes with light acidic undertones and some light funky ester. Body is about average with good carbonation. Well put together lambic mix except it may be a bit too balanced toward sour and acidic notes for my liking. I would have preferred more green apple and barnyard notes personally.

2010 bottle, pours a gorgeous almost glowing golden liquid under pale and lacy white head with low retention. Smells awesomely gueuze-y: lots of floral funk and meaty aromas with hints of sun-baked hay. Tastes very tame, somewhat peppery up front with undertones of the meatiness. Missing the bite that the Cantillon Classic has at the end which pervades over the whole mouth. This is definitely a little tamer... but oh so delicious. Mouthfeel is slightly dry and initially effervescent. Overall its definitely one of the better regular gueuzes Ive had; I wish I had cases of the stuff.

Best before 10/02/2021 - Poured into some Hill Farmstead stemware.  Slightly hazy golden yellow body with thin white head on top.  Earthy, sour, acidity on the nose.  Wet hay and orange.  Really nice nose on this.  Taste is soured oranges, earthy malts and a touch of dry brett.  Really nice blend between sour acidity and brett funk.  Palate is perfect.  Balanced acidity, good carbonation, slightly slick.  Overall, this was a really nice surprise and an excellent gueuze.  Right up there with Cantillon and Drie.  Flavor is more on the Cantillon side of things, but there is definitely some brett funk lingering in there.  Ill definitely need to pick up a few more of these.  Very excited to see how they age.

Other than the slight haze this has all the looks of a gueuze to me.  The aroma is really fruity, some graininess, some tartness, and a touch acidic.  Taste is also fruitier and really enjoyable.  Peach, lemon, some yogurt, and a tart finish.  Lighter bodied, and not as acidic as cantillon and 3F.  Really good, but not quite on the same level as other big gueuzes.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2012 Picked this up at Hill Farmstead Brewery. Poured into a Flute glass. The bottle was at cellar temp so around 55.

A - Pouring carefully, I still got a 5-finger head with a nice mix of bubbles that quickly resided. This is a pale yellow color almost like a lemonhead candy with a lot of carbonation.

S - Immensely tart scent with some light honeysuckle, floral and leafy scents. 

T - Excellent first taste upon hitting the tongue. Up front tart taste with a great earthy and dirt like taste and a lot of wood. On the back of the tongue, tongue tingling from a very sour taste. Overall, nicely balanced.

M - 90% carbonation on a mouth swish. Light bodied and very very dry. My mouth is left very dry and the aftertaste doesnt linger at all. Its gone pretty fast.

O - Very well balanced beer. Well done and very tasty.

2012 vintage update. Enjoyed from a 37CL bottle from hunger mountain. Much sweeter and more smooth and refined than before. Still an excellent Gueuze.

This poured a darker golden color with a fluffy white head. Aroma was acidic green apples, some barnyard funk, and some spicey yeastyness.  Flavor was fairly tart but not overwhelming, a good bit of grainy lemony notes and some light funk. Decent.

Had this at Ratebeers Horny Devil Pittsburgh Winter Tasting 2012. Big thanks to James for this gem.  Cloudy orange yellow. Very sweet tart purfumy aroma. Like many real lambics  simply dee-lish.  Good sour palate that is full of co2 impact, lovely. Really nice James! This Horny Devil rocks. When I think about limbic, I think about beers like this. Very good overall beer experience!

text: Bottle hazy yellow with a rim of bubbles.  Aroma is crisp apple and bright sour funk, really enticing.  The lactic sourness is just right and not too hard but not too soft.    Exceptional yeasty bitterness and chaulky mouthfeel with a lively envelope of soft bubbles.  Could drink this forever.
Bottle. Orange color.Really tart and mildy sweet. Really puckers the tongue but not over-doing it. Delicious, one of the best

Pretty solid, but I fell a hair short of my expectations based the recent surge in popularity of this beer.

.375ml bottle.  Pours light amber with a white head.  Nose is of funky cheese, lemon and leather.  Taste is funky cheese and lemon.  Mouthfeel is medium and very sour. This is one fantastic gueuze and Im glad I have a 750 ml bottle still.  This was one of the best gueuze Ive ever had.  Simply delightful.

S - Smells of citric fruits, dirty funk, green apples, oak and a touch of breadiness. Nothing too complex yet still very enjoyable.

It reminds me of a French Canadian tennis racket, stuck to the back of a Venus snow-goon, bubbling out of my sisters Brazilian donkey - I dont think I can make myself any clearer!

hazy yellow pour, small to no head. 
huge aromas or wet hay, and horse blanket, and wet grass. big amounts of funk, and tartness. mouthfeel is bang on, carbonation is perfect. the finish is very very tart, more and more as it warms. medium bitterness, with a great dose of funk in the end. great gueuze!

Mostly clear golden amber no head no lace... Funky cheesy aroma light lemon quite funky leathery... Cheesy lemony funky dry tart relatively lively lots Of lemon... Medium body..
Bottle shared by Ryan. Very tasty indeed! Great sour funk aroma with hints of lemon. Tart sour flavor that makes the cheeks pucker. Delicious.

A rating for an early bottling version with 1 and 2 year old blend only.  Usually treated as separate entries on ratebeer.  Another rating will be added for the 1, 2, 3 year old blend when I drink one of my bottles
In short: A classy, dry and complex citrusy Gueuze that is not too intensely sour/acidic.  Wow!
How: Bottle 750ml.  One of the early bottling from 2011 (1 year + 2 year lambic).  Consumed when approximately 8 months of age

Bottled. Pours hazy copper with a big white head. Smells and tastes clear sour, abit citrus with a similar finish.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 Best by date 09/02/2022; Sampled April 2013
A soft pour into my New Belgium globe glass produces a voluminous, quickly overflowing, four-finger thick, pale tan colored head; this leaves some light, layered lacing on the sides of my glass as it slowly subsides. The beer is a nice amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, bright, pale-amber tinged, full gold color when held up to the light. The aroma has a certain cider like note to it, this is backed by a solid lactic tartness, lots of woody mushroom notes, earthy oak character, a soft musky / sweaty character, piquant urea, some toasted oak notes, a nutty dried straw aroma, and then a solid fruit character in the finish again that also has some pear like notes to it. The aroma is quite complex, with a definite piquancy to it.

My first sip is effervescent, tart, oaky, slightly astringent, and then with a more biting sourness in the finish. The body has some lactic slickness and tannic structure to it, but is well balanced by the bubbly carbonation; it is really hard to find fault with the body, lots of carbonation (which I like in a Gueuze), with ample body for a beer this dry, yet still eminently quaffable. The finish is phenolic, perhaps a hint of medicinal notes, lots of grassy / dried-hay flavors, and a certain bitterness and oaky spiciness is also here. The malt character accentuates the straw like notes, but also provides a rounded wheat-cracker / rustic-white-bread-crumb like character in the middle of each sip. Quite musky, with plastic overtones, perhaps, with lots of sort of medicinal mushroom like flavors, . This does have quite a chewy, oak stave, woody flavor to it; perhaps a bit more than some Lambics, but it is clearly only playing a supporting role here; I wonder if it has to do with the newness of the barrels that this new Gueuze blender is having to use. This has a firmness to it somehow that is accentuated by a mineral, perhaps slightly metallic character, and these get mixed in with a cider like flavor that shows perhaps a touch of oxidation; the oxidation also adds a slightly nutty overtone to the malt / grain character here. Speaking of fruit, there are also some light grapefruit like notes, and at times, perhaps a touch of pear like notes.

I was expecting this to be a significant let down after the fantastic Girardin Black Label that I had last night, but this is certainly holding its own; not as funky, but perfectly complex and actually a bit more balanced than the latter. This is a big improvement over the first vintage (with only two years of Lambic blended) that I had; much more complex, balanced, and characterful, in fact it makes me realize that I over-inflated the previous vintage, but I excuse myself for that one, since I was so excited about there being a new Gueuze blender in town. With the slightly darker coloring, and the slight cider like notes, it seems that this has seen  a bit more oxidation during aging than most modern Gueuze manufacturers, but it is well in line with what I have had in previous years, and luckily is only a light touch; I wonder if it will have any implication on the aging potential of these beers, only one way to find out. I really love Gueuze, that is all.

As I pop the cork off this best by 10/02/2021 375ml bottle I get a waft of raspberries.  A steady pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a two finger thick, somewhat creamy textured, pale tan colored head.  The beer is a pale amber color that shows a bright, clear, orange-tinted, gold hue when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of lactic acid, grapefruit and a touch of cider that is backed by an ample funkiness that provides mushroom notes, phenolic funkiness, fruity oak character, dry woody spicy notes, perhaps a hint of clove even.  The nose has a bright fruitiness to it that makes this distinct compared to other Gueuzes; this adds a nice note and at times I would swear there are some raspberries here.  The nose is quite nice, dry and appetizing smelling, but with a fair amount of complexity; as one should expect of a Gueuze.

The beer has bright sourness to it that manages to be quite in control and suggests at notes of grapefruit.  This is backed by a funkiness that wasnt quite as pronounced as it was in the nose.  There is a fruitiness here in the flavor that again reminds me of raspberries; this might be accentuated by a touch of acetic character that isnt really at flavor threshold levels.  This has a dryness to it that is accentuated by some oak derived astringency and some phenolic character. The body of this beer is just about perfect for a Gueuze, light and refreshing, but with that characteristic slickness and texture to it that keeps this a long way from being watery.  The oak character seems to be a touch spicier and astringent than is usual for a Gueuze; given that this is a new Gueuze blender and that the barrels were newly sourced, that is not at all surprising.  As the beer warms up the woody character / oak gets more distinct and, along with the funkiness, makes me think of woody mushrooms.  The acidity also gets a bit more pronounced, almost sharp, though not quite harsh.

This is a damn good Gueuze already, I cant wait to have one that is a proper blend of 3, 2 and 1 year old Lambics. This definitely has me excited as this particular blend shows a lot of potential; it could use a more muted oak profile and the acidity might be a bit more rounded, but I really like the fruitiness and the funkiness, and even the oak and acidity.  I cant wait to get more vintages of this.

Pours a slightly hazy deep gold. Aroma of barnyard funk, lemons, sharp acidic citrus and some slight grain. Wonderful citrus, funkiness and tart fruitiness. Great complexity and balance. Leaves a very dry finish and mouth watering for more. Awesome beer.

My Bottom Line :  
Citrus fruit imbued with lactic suggestions pierce this Gueuzes attic dustiness, as fine cereals ride an ebullient effervescence. 

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A white head of foam floats atop the hazy golden amber.
-This was much more elegant than the Gueuze which preceded it, the HORAL Mega-Blend.
-The mouthfeel was as tight as the best Drie Fonteinens. Damn, this is an impressive beginning!
-Sourness is about as intense as Drie Fonteinen as well. Even if the flavor profile is as classy and cohesive as they come, the pungency of the sourness makes this a sipper (this is much more intense than a Boon Oude Gueuze, for example, which I consider to be beautifully drinkable).

Dark yellow coloured and unclear. Has a white head, medium duration. Heavy acidic aroma, barnyard and leather. Flavor starts moderate sweet and heavy acidic, finish lightly bitter and heavy acidic. Dry texture and moderate astringent. Harmonic.

bottle at papso 25 tasting.
cloudy orange, smooth white head.
very nice gueze aroma, soft, sharp, very sour , balanced.
flavor is sour, leather, faint sweet notes. pretty good, perhaps a little sweet, but the sweetness is very subtle.

Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, horseblanket, wheat, and lemons. The flavor is acidic with notes of wood, brettanomyces, malt, wheat, lemons, and horseblanket, leading to a tart finish. Thanks joergen for sharing.

Bottle 37,5 cl. Courtesy of joergen. Pours a cloudy opaque golden with a tiny off-white head. Tart and heavy dirty barnyard in the nose. Medium body, a little initial fruitiness but then dry and sulphurous barnyard - lots of fart here. A very decent, straight and authentic Gueuze. 141111

Bottle from Vienna Whole Foods.  Pours a slightly hazy orange-yellow with a thin white head.  Woody, funky aroma with hoppy herbal notes as well as citrus peel.  Light sweetness when it first hits the tongue.  Very tart and sour, but not acetic.  Dry citrus peel finish.  Very citrusy and lemony.  Not bad.

375 ml bottle bought @ Systembolaget and consumed on November 12. Pours hazy orange with a white head that dissipates while leaving no trace on the glass. Smell is sour and complex with hay, leather, grapefruit, grass and slight mineral/metallic hints. Taste is dry and sour and full-bodied with hay, leather, lemon, grapefruit and funk. Finish is dry and slightly sour with a barnyard feel to it. Very good and quite nice to see a new brand of oude gueuze!
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Heavy sour nice aroma. Some citrus. Powerfull heavy sour flavor. Long great finish. Creamy palate. Really nice gueuze.

Bottle, 375 ml. Hazy orange pour, tiny head. Aroma of sour lemons, citrus, stable. Medium sour taste, smooth, medium carbonation. Looks, smells, and tastes like a gueuze, a good one. A great suprise that I will make sure to keep in my cellar.
Bottle.This new gueuze was a surprise second to no one.Intense yellow colour,foam little  persistent taste very intense

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 multiple bottles.  2010-2011 batch. perfect appearance for geuze - tall, frothy, billowy white head on top of a turbid, effervescent and lightly cloudy gold body. strong musty esters and acids in the nose, its richness and depth is surprisingly similar to some of the best cantillon and girardin batches of late: earthy, sulfuric, musty and minerallic / gravel-like rustic yeast and acids with honey-tinged biscuit / cracker malt and dry, grassy hops.  intensely satisfying acid profile with medium-heavy oak barrel character.  lightly buttery at times, which tends to play well with the wheat and biscuit malt character.  highly acidic and musty, intensely quenching and all around an amazing batch of geuze.  side-by-side, a recent cantillon batch was blown out of the water by this tilquin vintage.

Disig gul vätska med ett litet skum. En riktigt torr Geuze med mycket ektoner och rejäl syra. Kanske någon blommig ton, mycket grape, och den där omisskännliga geuzekaraktären. Lång stram lätt besk eftersmak. Rätt på alla punkter, hästfilten sitter som en smäck.

bottle 375... medium gold, once inch white cap, light lace... nice aroma that reminds me of the draft version, musky, spider webs, tons of straw, medium sourness...  the taste is really smooth, medium sourness that lends to great drinkability, very farmy, wish it had a touch of sweetness then it would be crushable... indistinguishable from the draft for the most part

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2012 ++++ RE-RATE 21 May 2012 ++++12.7 ml corked and caged bottle purchased at Royal Liquors in Kansas City, Missouri. 2010 2011 on neck label. REF A 1011 stamped on the cork. Best before 10/02/2021.  Poured into a white wine glass.  The pour is a lightly hazed golden orange with a sparkly 1/2 inch head that settles quick (subsequent pours were hazed to cloudy). A bunch of active carbonation bubbles, pretty. The aroma is soft lemon citrus, balanced nicely with tart lactic sour, and some barnyard erthiness as it warms.  Nice balance between pleasant wild yeastiness and wood.  The taste is the tart citrus, along with lactic sourness - initially quite bright, then settles in nicely as the palate acclimates.  As with the nose, nice balance between tart sour and wild.  This is really smooth beer.  The palate is medium bodied, with soft fine carbonation and a clean tart finish.  Lovely gueuze. (8,4,9,4,16 - 4.1)

++++ ORIGINAL RATING 7 November 2011 ++++750 ml bottle shared by beastiefan2k. Best before 18/02/2021. Pour is a hazed golden yellow, with a smallish off white head. Aroma is vinegar sour, lemon citrus sour, and some yeasty bathroom odors. Complex, integrated and soft nose. Taste is initially the bright lemon sour, followed by pleasant barnyard aromas, some floral, and finishes with the yeast of the nose. Palate is medium bodied, coats the mouth nicely, great unfiltered mouth feel pleasant funk in the finish. Thanks for sharing this one Eugene. (7,4,8,4,15 - 3.8)

Bottle. 
Hazy orange with two fingers high dirt white head that fizzles out pretty fast and leaves some strokes of foam on the glass.
Lots of funky horse/barnyard etc. on the nose with a quite sharp note of paint but also lemons, orangesezt and apples.
Taste is pretty sour and puckering with lemon and apples and a slight caramel note creeping in the aftertaste. This is straight forward sour stuff. Classic. But also here some paint or chemicals.
Medium to bigger body with lively mushy carbonation.
Tasty and very sour, but a little one dimensional perhaps?
Bottled 75cl. A great gueuze. I reveled in every sip. Impressive and incredibly delicious.

hazy orange with a sticky white head, lots of lace. funky nose; citrus, cobwebs, leather, baryard, citrus.  Quite balanced flavor that is nicely tart and sour without being too acidic.   Will buy more bottles.

Turdferguson shard a bit of this with me. Bright hazy lemon rind yellow pour with two fingers of sticky white head. Nose was nice and funky with lots of lemon zest and some hay.  Dry zesty flavor with a nice acidity and bacterial funk.  Me gusta.

A nice gueuze, with a nice sourness and a little barrel funk, and lightly fruity malts. One drawback is that the finish tended toward feeling a bit empty, as if the malts just disappeared, leaving it very dry and thin. Amber, almost tea-like color, fizzy, not much head.

375ml Bottle:   Tart aroma of lambic, gueze, light barnyard, fruit, leather, and wood.  Poured amber/orange in color with a small, creamy, white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of small and medium-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is heavily tart and medium sweet.  Tastes of lambic, wood, leather, light band-aid, light funk, tart fruit, and deliciousness.  Medium body.  Mouth-puckering, then dry texture.  Lively carbonation.  Heavily tart, medium sweet, tart fruit, lambic, wood, gueze, slight funk, finish is dry.  Yum!

Bottle from Binnys. First off, I dont get why people always say that there is a "vinegar" taste in gueuze, because its not vinegar. Nothing like it. Anyway, onto my rate. Pours an attractive deep gold with orange. Head is very persistent. On the nose, lots of funk, lemon zest, faint bubblegum, yoghurt, straight lactic acid and horseblanket. Pretty sharp. On taste, it is markedly bitter and intensely sour. Deep layered acidity. Lots of sharpnes, but never turning acetic. Reminds a lot of the Cantillon or Hannssens Gueuze. Crazy sour and pretty remarkable stuff. The bitterness is a touch much, though. Very good beer.
Cloudy ororange coloured beer, just a lace as head. Totally not my style. Sour, spices, need more carbonation. I can imagine some people like this, bit for me its no good.

Bottle at Local Option, Chicago. October 22, 2011.

Hazy light amber with a medium white head. Nice funky aroma with citrus, grape, vinegar and some oak. The taste was dry and tart, really good and refreshing. I look forward to drink this beer again.

375 ml bottle pours cloudy orange with lots of carbonation and a thick, although quickly diminished white head. Aromas of lemons, slight skunk, and some pepper. Taste is classic gauze, tart, barnyard, sour apple, lemon, ans lactic. Body is light and finish is short, dry, and clean.  Very tasty.

Golden amber pour hazy thin layer of white head .... aroma is sweet and strong with a sugary side but mostly brett and funky barnyard ...... taste is dry and sour brett with a sweet sugary side and then a funky barnyard earthy flavor .... tart lemony with a dry tart finish ... a little too sweet not quite as tart/sour but its still solid and a nice drinking gueuze

This beer was average at best.  My least likeness for this beer was the appearance.  It had none.  No head and no lacing. Watery, thin, minimal carbonation and poor overall appearance.  My beer was likely contaminated as it was only brewed in 2011 qith a good until 2021.  The flavor was tart and acidic with sourness abound. Not a beer I would likely try again.

Bottle @ The BeerMongers...  Poured hazy golden orange with a white head that retained nicely.  Substantial bretty nose with funk and horseblanket. Satisfyingly dry with light fruits, tart yeast, citrus, musky funk, and little bit of a burning acidity towards the finish.

2010/2011 - REF A 1011 cork - 375mL

A - Hazy golden with finger of white head, leaves a ring with spotty lacing.

S - green apples, grass/hay, with lemon.

T - Taste is a nice balance of barnyard brett and lemon rind. Nothing too complex, similar to a Cuvee Rene at a few years.

M/D - prickly and dry, wears on the palate a little more than it should.

A pretty solid gueuze blending from the new guy in Belgium, which can probably only get better,

I sampled this next to a Girardin that was bottled within 6 months of the Tilquin, and the Girardin was the clear winner. I think it would be nice to do a side by side with all 4 of the lambics he uses to really get a feel.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2013 375 ml bottle from Etre Gourmet. Poured into 3F tumbler. Hazy, amber/orange liquid with medium light off-white head. Funky, sour aroma of lemons, apples, barnyard, wheat, wood, leather, earthy notes and nice brett. Taste is medium tart,  medium to high sour and light  sweet. Notes of apples, brett and wheat. Nice and fruity. Very balanced, drinkable and refreshing. Medium bodied with high, but soft carbonation and dry mouthfeel. Long, sour finish. Very well balanced and drinkable Gueuze. Not bad for a gueuzerie this young!

Bottled.
Pours a medium straw, cloudy, thin white head.
Complex, funky aromas, straw, Brett, horse, wheat, dried apples, earth, 
Bone dry, light to medium body, low (no?) bitterness, very acidic, low CO2.
Complex, very tart taste, funk, brett, straw, hay, apples, citrus, earth.
Long, acidic finish. (2011-10-08)

Bottle.  Bubbly and fizzy white head that leaves a spotty white time with limited lacing; very hazy vibrant bright orange.   Leather, funk, slight cheese, musk and hay in the aroma. Very tart and sour up-front, with less leather and more sour hay, grass, and funk in the flavor.  Much more sour in the finish rather than funky, and hay-like is the overriding finishing note.  Lighter body with nice tight bubbly carbonation.  Tasty, but not quite as stunning as the best blenders.
UPDATED: OCT 16, 2011 Outstanding gueuze with smooth sour flavours, typical aroma and tiny bubbles texture.

Light hazy orange pour with a small fizzy white head. Aroma was light lemon, vinegar and a slight funkiness. Flavors were incredibly dry with notes of lemon, vinegary, and a lingering tartness. Mouthfeel was fizzy and dry.  Actually pretty tasty and drinkable.

Bottle. No head. Dark dirty amber. Strong salty aroma with a bit of funk. Big sour kick in the gums. Very nice first impression. Big, bold and sour with a fair amount of sweetness in the aftertaste. Keeps on going with a rough woody sourness that stretches out.

375ml bottle.  Best before 15/02/2021.  $11.50 at local store.    So this is the 1-2 year blend without 3yo cantillon is my understanding.   Aroma is bright lemon, dust, wood, faint apricot.  Pleasant, but not very potent.  taste is a potent punch of bright lemon, fresh cut grass, moderate-heavy yogurt acid, with some heavy juicy grapefruit character.   some wood.   Pretty good, but seems young.   Looking forward to more beers from this brewery.

375 ml bottle shared by pinkfloyd4ever at The Royale- thanks, Kevin! Pours a cloudy golden color with a small white head that dissipates into a sticky ring. Aroma of dairy funk, lemon, lactic acid, yogurt, herbs, oak, and white grape skins. Flavor of dry funk, oak, herbs, lemon, yogurt, and tart fruit skins. Medium-bodied, with a tart, acidic, dry, funky mouthfeel and medium-sharp carbonation. Probably will get even better in the bottle over the next couple years. Really nice.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2011 Bottle at Akkurat, Stockholm. 26th September 2011. 

Pours golden with a nice snow white head. Sour, acidic and very tart aromas of apples, lemons, barnyard and horseblanket. Its very refreshing with a soft carbonation. More tangy and sourish flavours in the taste with a lot of apple tart. No sweetness at all. Its very sour and pretty hardcore but it taste great and I cant wait to drink it again!

10/9/11. 375mL bottle. Light amber pour, basically golden orange, with a big, fluffy off-white head that laces plenty. Tart aroma that is a bit funky with lemon peel, vinegar, and a bit of sweetness. Tart, puckering flavor at first, vinegar and lemon juice, that fades to a bit of malt and a touch of metal. Maybe a bit watered down, but tasty nonetheless.

Bottle from Bierkoning, Amsterdam, Netherlands, Sat 1st October 2011 consumed Sun 2nd October 2011.   Pours hazy amber with a thin white rim of bubbles. Classic funky nose, touch farmy, its frizzy, tangy, zappy and a little funky in mouth, marvelous stuff I say!  A8 A3 T8 P4 Ov16  3.9
Bottle @ chriso. Pours a hazy yellow color with a white head. Has a fruity sour yeasty and tart funky aroma. Fruity sour tart citrus flavor. Has a fruity sour funky finish.

750 @ redlight redlight.   Spicy lemon on the nose with a hint of candied citrus.  Pours a hazy gold with a very thick white head ad nice carbonation.  Tart lemon upfront with a hint of lime and Brett Funk and old wood.  Lovely gueuze

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Tart/sour aroma with oak, fruitiness, and some earth. Tart/sour flavor with earth and light citrus. Medium bodied. Tart/sour notes linger with earth, light oak, and light fruitiness. I like it.

[9/24/11] Mahleket Hanikot Shotrim 11 tour. Bottle at Akkurat in Stockholm. 2010-2011 bottle. Hazy orange color with a big white head. Funky brett aroma with some citrus, a bit of leather and vinegar notes. Very sour prickly flavor with lemon and some barnyard. Medium-bodied, leaves a dry mouth. A tasty Gueuze.

Pours gold into a tumbler. Bright white head with excellent retention recedes leaving trailing sheets. Aspirin, grapefruit and sour funk aromas. Dry with sour grapefruit front to back and throught the lasting tart finish. Nice.

375ml bottle. Pours a cloudy, light amber color with a white head. Aroma is sour, funky, citrus, lemon. A little light on the palate with lively carbonation. Flavor is sour, but not as sour as it smells, lemon, a little bread, with a tart, dry finish. Pretty tasty. A good beer to introduce someone to sours.

Bottle (RBESGG2011, Grand Tasting)
Lovely woody gueuze aroma. Buttery in the body, woody resins too. Very crisp, but a bit sweet too. Classic gueuze, but a bit smoother and buttery. Finish leaves me wanting more.

Bottle, bought @ Beer Planet, Brussels.
Hazy, quite yellow with a small, creamy, white head that stays for a good while. Aroma has strong citrus, barnyard, brett, mild lactic acid. A bit of nuttiness in the back, light wheaty. Mild carbonation, light spritzy at first, then turns very dry. Flavour has good citric acid, dry bretty, very mild lactic. A very fresh-feeling gueuze. Lovely woody elegance in the finish. Lovely gueuze.

Bottle from Sams, pricey little bastard but what a classy label. Pours bright, hazy golden with orange hue. Nose of lemon oil, leather, barnyard, green apple peel. Taste similar, but more citric. Palate a bit thin, and the taste hits a slightly thin note as well. Still, quite good.

Bottle at RBESG 2011 Grand Tasting at The Dean Swift, London. Pours cloudy gold with a fluffy, white head. Good grass character, also some tangy citrus. Sour, lightly sweet flavor, grassy bitterness. Medium bodied with smooth, massaging carbonation. Grassy, sour finish. Very drinkable and very refreshing.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2012 Pours a cloudy orange color with a thin head to it. Has a funky, citrus. horse blanket smell to it. Taste is very similar with a nice mixture of sourness, funk and a slight bitter finish.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2011 Drank this one on drought at the brewery and didnt find it good. I only drank the cold ones, which I really dont like in a geuze.
Took some boxes home to give it a try and imo this geuze gets better after 6 months. I guess the blender didnt leave its geuze long enough on the barrel. While Armand leaves it one year, Tilquin left it 6 months.
bottle 37.5cl (till 21-01-2021)
Its a bit like a Girardin, a not so sour geuze, very drinkeable. A nice beginner geuze. Orange-brown, head dissapears quickly. Aroma is citrus, apple. Flavour is again citrus, sour, but not too sour. Cantillon-Girardin is recognisable in it.

2010-2011 bottle at t Antwaerps Bierhuiske. Pours a golden colour with a fair white head. Lovely aroma of horse-blanket, wet hay and lemon. Nice and tart with balsamic vinegar and pickled onion flavours and a foamy mouth-feel. Also flavours of musty honey, lemon, white pepper and lemon rind. Mouth-puckering sourness with a little dry linger. I really like this!
Bottle. I really like gueuze when its as young and fresh as this one! I get a lot of really sour pear notes. There is some fruit-like sweetness in the background. Dry finish with a woody aftertaste.
This is the newest Geuze around with lambics from the finest order. Just lovely balanced, just haven !

Bottle at Stone Brewery. Pours murky golden with almost no head and an acidic fruit aroma. There is a carbonated fruity flavor that exhibits the mellow slightly tart character of a tradtionally blended geueze. A brilliant addition to the lambic scene.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 (bottle) pours a hazy golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of citrus fruits, peppery spices, light seaweed, vanilla, biscuits, rose petals and young gouda cheese. flavour is mostly citrus fruits, with a hint of brown sugar, lavender and a very tart finish. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.

Bottle sampled at the sour tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 9/15/11. Hazy gold pour with a thick white head. Aroma of slight dogshit, baby vomit, pepper and lemon. Lemon juice flavor with bretty funk and a tart citrus finish.

2011 bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy yellow to hay color with slight head that lingers. Nose is funky sour that is not over powering. First sip is nicely balanced with tart and dry. Mouth feel is pleasant.finish is slight bitter not from hops almost aspirin like, but dry.
En botella.Color naranja un poco turbia,con corona de espuma fina,bien carbonatada.En boca empieza un poco dulce, con un final mas ácido .Aromas  discretas.

Sampled at spuytin duyvil with Linh, VI, Thi and Ken. Pours a bright, hazy orange body with no head. Aroma is delicious citrusy yeast, funk, fruit. Mouthfeel is smooth but carbonated with funky fruit notes and champagne yeast.

One of my friends told me that this was good, so I figured Id try it!  12.7 ounce caged and corked bottle, best before date of 15/02/2021, $9.99 a bottle.  Served in a flute, the beer pours a hazy golden/orange color with about a half inch off-white head that went away quickly.  Not much lacing left on the glass.  The brew smells like hay, lemon peel, sweet and tart apples, and some oak and funk.  The tartness is noticable but not strong in the aroma. I think its a good brew, Ill have to buy another bottle of this and age it for a while.

375mL shared by Jay. Thanks. Hazy straw golden with a one finger white, fair retention. Loads of lemon tartness with plenty of musty cobwebs, old wood. Sourness is restrained in the flavor, even a bit of sweetness following through to an earthy bitter finish. Bitterness 3-4, sourness 4. Light Carb, light body. Not bad, pretty bitter.

text: 750 shared by Todd!  Thx!  Hazy straw gold pour with a fizzy white head.  Spirizty carbonation.  Light funk and barnyard on the nose.  You really pick up the cantillon here.  Light to moderate acidity.  Lemon grass, horse blanket, dusty white grapes and dank basement

375ml bottle.  Large white head, lightly hazed light amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, barnyard, lacto, some funk, lemon.  Taste is medium sweet, lemon, lacto, some funk.  Light body, somewhat soft.  Less pungent than the draft version.

Bottle at In De Verzekering Tegen De Grote Dorst last Sunday. Actually purchased by a local who bought a round, and this was recommended by Yves. At that point, it may have been one of the only things on the menu we hadnt tried! Served in a lambic basket and reviewed from notes.

Poured into a Girardin tumbler.

Poured a nice straw color with a good white head that is a bit fizzy. A bit of lacing, though not a ton. The nose brings forward a good dosing of citrus. Not nearly as cheesy as the draft version. Good citrus flavor and light funk. Bright acidity. Light body and a dry, lightly-puckering finish. Really great for the first run, and something I was very glad to try.

Bottle
